texts.shortText:
Members of the family Spionidae are fairy easily recognized, as they have a characteristic pair of elongated, grooved palps extending from the otherwise fairly featureless pointed or rounded head. Otherwise most are small and slender.

This species has a pointed head that lacks any other appendages other than the elongated palps. The fifth segment is not swollen or otherwise modified and there are simple strap-like gills on the parapodia from segment 2 backwards. It is the most abundant worm on sandy beaches in sandy pools and in lagoonal areas, where it can attain very high densities.

Global: Widely distributed on both sides of the Atlantic, including  the Mediteranean and Caribbean and around South Africa to Mozambique and Madagascar.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.

Live in mucus-reinforced sandy vertical burrows excavated in sand. Sometimes these tubes are so abundant that the surface layer of sand is fused into a crust perforated by numerous holes. The palps are extended from the opening of the tube and can be used to gather food from the water column, or from the sediment surface.

Feed on either suspended particles or those on the sediment surface. Examination of gut contents (in Northern hemisphere populations) showed the food to include organic and inorganic sediment particles, faecal pellets of other animals and a variety or larvae and small invertebrates.

In the UK breeds from March to July, releasing sperm and eggs into the water column. These develop into planktonic larval with a duration of about five weeks. Growth is rapid and the worm has a short lifespan of about a year.

Fairly easily recognised to group because of the long, grooved palps (although similar palps do also occur in a few other families). There are over 40 regional species in the family though and these require detailed microscopic examination to identify to species level. However, this species is by far the most common member of the group to be found on regional sandy beaches and mixed shores.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Dauer, DM (1983). Functional morphology and feeding behavior of Scolelepis squamata (Polychaeta: Spionidae). Marine Biology, 77(3), 279-285.

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 485).
